choices.text: 3 and 4 are true, 1 and 2 are false.
2 and 4 are true, 1 and 3 are false.
1 and 4 are true, 2 and 3 are false.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true and which are false?
1. On X-ray chest PA view, the anterior surface of the heart is formed by the left atrium
2. The angle of tracheal bifurcation is increased in left atrial enlargement
3. Plethoric lung fields are seen in conditions that decrease pulmonary blood flow
4. The right heart border on CXR is formed by the SVC, the right atrium, and the IVC
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Statement 1 is false. In a chest X-ray taken in the posteroanterior (PA) view, the; anterior surface; of the heart is primarily formed by the; right ventricle, not the left atrium.; The left atrium is positioned posteriorly and to the left of the right ventricle.
  • Statement 2 is true. Left atrial enlargement can lead to an increased angle of tracheal bifurcation, which is known as the; 'angle of Louis'. This is due to the enlarged left atrium pushing the mainstem bronchi downward and causing them to take a more horizontal course, resulting in a wider angle of bifurcation.
  • Statement 3 is false. Plethoric lung fields refer to increased lung markings or vascular congestion, which are typically seen in conditions that ;increase pulmonary blood flow, such as; left-to-right cardiac shunts or pulmonary hypertension. Conditions that; decrease pulmonary blood flow, such as; pulmonary embolism or severe pulmonary artery stenosis, typically result in decreased lung markings or; pulmonary oligemia.
  • Statement 4 is true. On a chest X-ray (CXR), the; right heart border; is indeed formed by the; superior vena cava (SVC), right atrium, and inferior vena cava (IVC).

questions.text: Which of the following radiological features are indicative of left atrial hypertrophy on chest radiograph?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Left atrial hypertrophy produces a characteristic set of radiographic signs:

  • Double atrial shadow: The enlarged left atrium projects through the right atrium and appears as an additional density on the right side of the cardiac silhouette. (Option A ruled out)
  • Elevation of the left main bronchus: The enlarged left atrium pushes the bronchus upward, resulting in a widened carinal angle. (Option B ruled out)
  • Straightening of the left heart border: Loss of the normal concavity of the mid-left heart border due to left atrial enlargement creates a straight or even convex outline. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A CT Angiography of a patient with polycythemia vera is shown below. The thrombus lies in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT axial image demonstrates a filling defect (thrombus) within the contrast-opacified left pulmonary artery, consistent with pulmonary embolism.
  • In polycythemia vera, hyperviscosity and thrombogenic tendencies often lead to vascular thrombosis, with pulmonary arteries being a common site.
  • The posterior-most chamber of the heart is the Left Atrium, and the yellow arrow points towards a thrombus inside the left pulmonary artery.

Explanation for other options:

Right pulmonary artery (Option A): Incorrect, as the thrombus is not located in the vessel branching to the right lung field.

Right pulmonary vein (Option C): Incorrect, pulmonary veins are usually posterior structures returning oxygenated blood to the left atrium and appear smaller and less central than the artery shown.

Left pulmonary vein (Option D): Incorrect, this lies inferiorly and more posterior to the artery and would not show this pattern of thrombus on angiography.

questions.text: A patient presenting with breathlessness and pedal oedema gives a history of an MI a few years back. A chest radiograph is taken and shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Pericardial effusion

  • The chest radiograph of a pericardial effusion may show a ;globular enlargement of the cardiac silhouette,often described as a 'water bottle' ;shape, which is characteristic of significant fluid accumulation in the pericardium.
  • This condition involves theaccumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac.
  • The investigation of choice is echocardiography.

However, the following x-ray findings are also characteristic of pericardial effusion:

AP view - money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart

Lateral view - Oreo cookie sign (fluid is seen between two layers of fat)

Explanation of other opinions:

Constrictive pericarditis (Option B): While this condition also presents with breathlessness and symptoms of heart failure, it typically shows pericardial calcifications and a normal or slightly enlarged heart size on a chest radiograph.

Cardiac tamponade (Option C): This is an acute emergency with fluid accumulation causing pressure on the heart, leading to hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. The radiograph might show an enlarged cardiac silhouette (Money bag appearance), but the presentation is more acute and severe than described.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D): This typically presents with an enlarged heart on the radiograph and symptoms of heart failure, including breathlessness and pedal oedema.

questions.text: A patient presented with features of heart failure, and on undergoing a CT scan, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given CT image shows calcified pericardium. It is typically seen in constrictive pericarditis.
  • Patients with constrictive pericarditisfrequently present with symptoms of heart failure such as dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue, and occasionally with liver enlargement and ascites.
  • The diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis is aided by CT and MRI imaging. Pericardial thickness of 4 mm or more indicates abnormal thickening, and when accompanied by clinical findings of heart failure, it is highly suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.
  • The below X-ray shows the egg-in-cup appearance suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Explanation of other options:

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): This is an acute emergency with fluid accumulation causing pressure on the heart, leading tohypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. But the presentation is more acute and severe than described.

Pleural effusion (Option C) causes accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity and shows the following signs: Meniscus sign, Ellis curve, Obliteration of costophrenic angle.

Pericardial effusion (Option D): The chest radiograph of a pericardial effusion shows enlargement of cardiac silhouette, often described as a 'water bottle' shape, which is characteristic of significant fluid accumulation in the pericardium.

questions.text: Egg on side appearance is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The 'egg on side' or 'egg on a string' appearance refers to the narrow mediastinum with an enlarged cardiac silhouette, typically seen in Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA).
  • This classic radiographic sign results from the anteroposterior relationship of the great vessels and the straightened superior mediastinum due to narrowing of the thymic shadow and pulmonary artery.

Explanation of other options:

Ebstein anomaly (Option A): Atrialisation of right ventricle, Box-shaped heart. Maternal Lithium use is a risk factor.

Tricuspid atresia (Option C) will show a prominent Right heart border and small RV and will not show an egg on string appearance.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option D) will show a Boot-shaped heart.

questions.text: A 2-year-old cyanotic child presents with failure to thrive and recurrent respiratory tract infections. A chest X-ray reveals a markedly globular cardiac silhouette with oligemic lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer :

  • Ebstein's anomaly - Box car appearance, right atrial enlargement, narrow vascular pedicle, oligemic lung fields (also seen in tricuspid atresia).
  • Ebstein anomaly is characterised by an abnormal tricuspid valve that is displaced downwards into the right ventricle.
  • Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle.
  • There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis.

X-ray findings seen are:

  • Enlarged right atrium- causes severe right-sided cardiomegaly
  • Pulmonary oligemia

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A): Presents with a boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy and upturned apex.

TAPVC (Option B): Usually presents with pulmonary plethora and a snowman or figure-of-8 heart shape on X-ray.

TGA (Option D) shows Egg on side/egg on string appearance, this is due to altered cardiac contours because of cardiomegaly.

questions.text: Match the following appearances with the following diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

a:- Egg-on-string appearance - seen in Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) due to narrowed superior mediastinum with enlarged cardiac shadow.

b:- Box-shaped heart - classic for Ebstein anomaly, due to right atrial enlargement

c. Scimitar sign - associated with Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC), especially the Scimitar variant.

d. Goose-neck sign - occurs in Endocardial cushion defect, showing elongated left ventricular outflow tract on imaging.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with breathlessness and cyanosis. A chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given image shows boot boot-shaped heart, which is seen in TOF.
  • It is the most common cause of cyanotic heart defects in children.

TOF is a congenital cardiac anomaly comprising the following four components:

  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Overriding aorta
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Other radiographic features seen in TOF are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal-sized heart without heart failure
  • Right-sided aortic arch (in 25% cases)

Explanation of other options:-

Ebstein anomaly (Option B): Characterised by atrialization of the right ventricle due to downward displacement of the tricuspid valve.
Radiograph shows a box-shaped heart, marked right atrial enlargement, and oligemic lung fields.
Cyanosis is seen, but the heart shape is not boot-shaped.

TGA (Option C) Classically shows the egg-on-a-string appearance on chest X-ray.Due to a narrowed mediastinum (from anteroposterior great vessel orientation) and a globular cardiac shadow.Common cause of cyanosis in neonates, not typically in a 5-year-old.

TAPVC (Option D): Commonly presents with snowman sign (particularly in supracardiac type) due to dilated vertical vein and left SVC. The heart shadow may appear enlarged, but not boot-shaped. Pulmonary venous congestion may be present depending on the type and obstruction.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with dizziness and light-headedness. Upon general examination, blood pressure in the upper extremities is higher than lower extremities, and there is a prominent brachial-femoral delay in blood pressure measurements. A continuous "machine-like" murmur is auscultated in the left infraclavicular area. His Radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The history and radiograph given are suggestive of coarctation of the aorta; there is visible inferior rib notching known as Rosler's sign, and a reverse 3 sign in the aorta can be seen too.
  • Co-arctation of the aorta most commonly occurs just beyond the left subclavian artery and leads to a difference in BP of the upper and lower extremities.

Causes for inferior rib notching (Roesler sign) are:

  • It occurs due to erosion of the inferior margins of ribs by dilated intercostal collateral vessels that are formed to bypass the coarctation
  • It is a late feature and is unusual in patients < 5 years of age
  • Ribs 4-8 are commonly notched, and ribs 1-2 are usually spared

Unilateral:

  • Subclavian artery occlusion:-Coarctation of the aorta involving left subclavian or anomalous right subclavian artery

Bilateral:

  • Coarctation of the aorta, occlusion, aortitis
  • Takayasu's disease and atheroma of the subclavian artery
  • Pulmonary oligemia (ToF, pulmonary atresia, stenosis)
  • SVC or IVC obstruction
  • AV malformation
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1

Explanation of other options:

Ebstein anomaly (Option B): Atrialisation of right ventricle, Box-shaped heart, Maternal Lithium use is the risk factor.

TGA (Option C) shows Egg on side/egg on string appearance, this is due to altered cardiac contours because of cardiomegaly.

TAPVC (Option D): Snowman/Cottage loaf/figure of 8 appearance.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath, orthopnea, and bilateral lower extremity oedema. On physical examination, there is increased jugular venous distention and crackles in the lung bases are noted. Diagnosis of congestive cardiac failure is made based on the radiograph below. What is the stage of Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • CHF stage in the given question can be determined by either the PCWP value or X-ray features. From the above radiograph, one can determine that there is significant alveolar oedema, which gives a characteristic batwing appearance, making it CHF stage 3.
  • Stage 1 - PCWP 12-18mg, X-ray shows reverse moustache sign (Option A)
  • Stage 2 - PCWP 18-25mg, X-ray shows Kerley lines (Option B)
  • Stage 3 - PCWP >25mg, X-ray shows batwing appearance.
  • Stage 4- (not conventionally used as a stage for CHF) Characterised by pleural effusions in addition to the signs of Stage 3. (Option D)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with pain in the flank, hypotension and pulsatile abdominal mass, and the following image is obtained on CECT. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The above findings of hypotension and pulsatile abdominal mass, along with CECT suggestive of aortic aneurysm with high attenuation fluid in the left side of the retroperitoneum and surrounding the aneurysm sac, favour to a ruptured aortic aneurysm.
  • The classical triad of pain, hypotension, and pulsatile abdominal mass due to rupture into the retroperitoneum is only seen in 25-50% of patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm.
  • In cases of contained rupture of an aortic aneurysm, retroperitoneal haemorrhage adjacent to the aneurysm is the most common finding.
  • This haemorrhage can extend into the perirenal or pararenal spaces or the psoas muscles.
  • Intraperitoneal extension may also occur, either immediately or later.
  • An important sign is the draped aorta sign, where the posterior wall of the aorta is not distinct from adjacent structures, and the contour of the aorta follows that of adjacent vertebrae.

Explanation of other options:

Aortic dissection (Option B) typically presents with severe tearing chest or back pain. Imaging reveals an intimal flap separating true and false lumens within the aorta, best seen on CT angiography. Dissections more commonly involve the thoracic aorta than the abdominal aorta.

Acute Pancreatitis (Option C) presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back. CT findings include enlarged pancreas, peripancreatic fat stranding, and fluid collections. There is no pulsatile mass or retroperitoneal hematoma associated with pancreatitis as seen in this image.

Angiomyolipoma (Option D) is a benign renal tumour composed of fat, muscle, and blood vessels. It appears as a well-defined, fat-density lesion on CT and may rarely bleed spontaneously, but lacks the characteristic aneurysmal appearance of the aorta.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of systemic sclerosis presents with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and chest discomfort. On physical examination, she has accentuated P2 and a tricuspid regurgitant murmur. Echocardiography reveals an elevated right ventricular systolic pressure and a dilated right ventricle. The radiograph and pulmonary angiogram are givenbelow. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given images show prominence of the central pulmonary artery with peripheral hypovascularity, depicting pulmonary hypertension.
  • In the angiogram, the classical prune tree appearancecan also be seen.
  • All these radiological findings are consistent with the given presentation of the patient suffering from PAH.

The plain radiograph findings in Pulmonary artery hypertension include:

  • Elevated cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Enlarged right atrium
  • Prominent pulmonary outflow tract
  • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
  • Pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

Explanation of other options:

Sarcoidosis (Option B) shows the bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, not the prune tree appearance.

Pneumothorax (Option C) will show absence of bronchovascular markings and deep sulcus sign, not the prune tree appearance.

Pulmonary thromboembolism (Option D) will show its typical signs, Palla's sign and westermark sign and Hampton's hump not the prune tree appearance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with the sudden onset of severe chest pain showing ST elevation on ECG after a stressful emotional outburst. Angiography Findings are normal, but cardiac imaging demonstrates ballooning of the left ventricle in systole with akinesia of the distal part of the LV wall. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Takotsubu Cardiomyopathy

  • Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy, also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathyor 'broken heart syndrome', is characterised by transient left ventricular dysfunction, typically following a stressful emotional or physical event.
  • Cardiac imaging, such as echocardiography or cardiac MRI, typically reveals a distinctive pattern of left ventricular ballooning or apical akinesia, resembling the shape of a Japanese octopus trap, which gives the condition its name 'Tako-Tsubo' (Japanese for 'octopus trap').
  • In Tako-Tsubo Cardiomyopathy, the mid and apical segments of the left ventricle exhibit akinesia or dyskinesia, while the basal segments typically maintain normal or hyperdynamic function.

Explanation of other options:

Constrictive pericarditis (Option A): While this condition presents with breathlessness and symptoms of heart failure, it typically shows pericardial calcifications and a normal or slightly enlarged heart size on a chest radiograph.

HOCM (Option B): HOCM typically presents with hypertrophy of the left ventricle, particularly the septum, and may lead to dynamic outflow tract obstruction. HOCM imaging shows banana-shaped ventricles.

Dilated Cardiomyopathy (Option D): Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterised by left ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction. While it can present with symptoms similar to heart failure, the sudden onset of severe chest pain and transient left ventricular dysfunction seen in Tako-Tsubo Cardiomyopathy are not typical of dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presented with dragging chest pain. The following CT image was obtained, What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given CT scan showing a double lumen and dilatation of the aorta is suggestive of an aortic dissection.
  • Aortic dissection occurs when blood enters the medial layer of the aortic wall through a tear or penetrating ulcer in the intima and tracks longitudinally along the media, forming a second blood-filled channel (false lumen) within the vessel wall.
  • Chest radiography may be normal or may show a widened mediastinum of more than 8 cm with an ill-defined large aortic knob with medially displaced intimal calcification when compared with prior radiographs.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT will demonstrate the site and extent of dissection. CT angio is recommended for stable patients with an acute presentation.
  • MR is good for follow-up, and transesophageal echo is often obtained in unstable patients at the bedside.

Aortic aneurysm (Option A) will present as a pulsatile mass and will be asymptomatic in most cases. It shows fusiform or saccular dilatation of the vessel without an intimal flap.

Pulmonary artery thrombus (Option C) will have the presence of thrombus inside the vessel, which is not appreciable in the given CT section.

Cardiac neoplasm (Option D) will remain asymptomatic in most cases and will remain as a intraluminal/intra arterial or intraventricular defect.

questions.text: Make a diagnosis based on the X-ray and CT provided?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The X-ray and the CT show the presence ofa right-sided aortic arch.
  • The aortic arch normally curves to the left. A right-sided arch is seen arching over the right mainstem bronchus and trachea.
  • The right arch with mirror image branching is associated with cyanotic congenital heart disease.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is the most likely diagnosis in the setting of a cyanotic heart lesion with right aortic arch.

Explanation of other options:

Normal (Option A): The X-ray and the CT show the presence of a right-sided aortic arch, which is not seen in a normal X-ray.

Anomalous pulmonary vein (Option C) can be total or partial, and it will show a Figure of 8 appearance or Scimitar appearance.

Double aortic arch (Option D): The X-ray and the CT show the presence of a right-sided aortic arch, not the double aortic arch.
